title: Call with Franklin About His Announcement

screenplay.rawText: Jason calls Franklin to discuss the mysterious announcement Catherine hinted at. Franklin congratulates Jason for completing the commission on time, grants the full bonus, then reveals the shocking truth: he plans to publicly offer a $50,000 prize to anyone who can successfully steal Jason’s commissioned painting from the art show.
actions: Jason pulls out his phone and dials Franklin.
The phone rings and Franklin answers promptly.
Franklin congratulates Jason for earning the $5,000 bonus.
The tone abruptly shifts when Franklin reveals his 'announcement.'
Jason reacts with growing disbelief and anger.
Franklin frames the theft challenge as performance art — drama as his artistic medium.
He demands that Jason fulfill his contract and attend the reception.
Jason turns to Stacey, stunned and spiraling.
Stacey confirms the situation is indeed strange.
Jason asks Stacey to stop filming so he can decompress.

lines: Hello Jason.
Fantastic! My commission is finished on time, and you have earned your five thousand dollar bonus. Congratulations!
Easy, yes. The bonus was for my peace of mind. I wanted you to stay focused.
Of course... I meant no offence.
Such a perfect segway to my announcement... I’m offering a fifty thousand dollar prize to anyone who can steal our commission from the current art show.
Yes! Isn’t that exciting?
You say crazy... I say what a fun story we’ll have to tell when this is all over.
That’s lazy thinking... I am an art collector, and I love doing business with artists to support their creativity.
However, I am an artist too. My medium is different than yours.
My medium is brewing drama for the story. This is our story.
You can call it what you want. I just need you to fulfill the contract.
Be present at the art reception for the announcement.
Fantastic! Good day.
Hey, Franklin. How are you?
Well I appreciate the bonus. It was easy enough, I usually paint these pieces within two weeks anyway.
I understand why you might think that, but I’m not focused by the money.
I’ve spent so many years making art with very little monetary return on my investment.
Wait— what!? Are you serious?
You pay me a total of twenty grand for a commission. Then, before you take possession, you’re going to prompt someone to steal it for fifty grand?
Exciting?! It’s fucking mad. You’re crazy!
Sure, drop a total of seventy grand for a painting you’ll never have — for a story to tell. That does sound crazy to me.
Your art is a drama show? You’re bonkers.
I’ll be there.
Can you believe this?
Am I crazy?... This is crazy.
Very odd.
Sure.

narrative.summary: Jason confronts Franklin about the mysterious 'announcement' coming at the art show. Franklin reveals a shocking twist: he will publicly offer $50,000 to anyone who can steal the commissioned painting from the gallery. Franklin frames the act as 'art' itself — drama as his medium. Jason is horrified, bewildered, and emotionally shaken.
narrative.beatPurpose: Escalate the stakes dramatically; reveal Franklin’s philosophy; transform the commission from a quirky job into a dangerous and chaotic artistic experiment.
narrative.conflict: Jason’s desire for stability and professionalism clashes with Franklin’s chaotic, manipulative, performance-art worldview.
stakes: The painting may actually be stolen.
Jason’s reputation and safety are now at risk.
The entire project has turned into a volatile spectacle.
narrative.outcome: Jason is furious but contractually trapped. He must attend the reception and face the theft challenge being announced.

emotionalShifts.Jason: Hopeful → Appreciated → Confused → Shocked → Angry → Existential crisis

continuityLinks: Leads directly to the art reception scene where Franklin makes the announcement.
Introduces real-world danger and potential for criminal chaos at the show.
